events.name: FOSSASIA Summit 2017
events.description:
Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Personal Assistants is the tagline of Asia's Premier Open Technology Summit 2017 at the Science Centre Singapore. 

The event is taking place for the third time in Singapore, after events in Vietnam and Cambodia. The FOSSASIA Summit is a tech focused event for developers, designers, start-ups, and contributors. Project presentations range from open hardware, to design, graphics and software. 

A dedicated Tech Kids track offers sessions such as build websites on GitHub, develop Android applications and learn how to deploy applications online. 

FOSSASIA was established in 2009 and develops Open Tech solutions for social change. We run coding programs, organize meetups and conferences across Asia.

Official Website: http://2017.fossasia.org
Science Centre Singapore: http://www.science.edu.sg
Tickets are available at: https://eventyay.com/e/45da88b7/
events.location: Science Centre Singapore, 15 Science Centre Road 609081

events.name: ArtScience on Screen: Space Films
events.description:
Dates and Screening Times: 
17 – 19 Mar: ET
Friday 17th March: 11AM, 1PM, 3PM, 5PM, 7PM
Saturday 18th March: 11AM, 1PM, 3PM, 5PM
Sunday 19th March: 11AM, 1PM, 3PM, 5PM

20 – 22 Mar and 27 – 29 Mar: Wonders of the Solar System
10AM - 7PM Shown in a continuous loop

Venue: Expression Gallery, Level 4
Free Admission

Explore a wide selection of exciting space adventures! Experience the unexpected companionship of artificial intelligence and the wonders of our solar system with Professor Brian Cox and imagine what challenges we would face if we discovered alternative lifeforms in space.

During Family Fridays, we revisit a number of classic children sci-fi adventures, and discover what happens when dreams of building your own spacecraft become reality or when a friendly alien comes to live with you.

#ArtScienceOnScreen

http://po.st/SpaceFilmsMBS

events.name: Friday Hacks #131: Weapons of Math Destruction
events.description:
Hi folks! This week we are privileged to have one of the leading experts in high performance computing (he has his own law!), give a talk on the intricacies of math in computing. For more information, refer to the talk description.

Title: Weapons of Math Destruction

Talk Description:
A new data type called a "posit" is designed for direct drop-in replacement for IEEE Standard 754 floats. Unlike unum arithmetic, posits do not require interval-type mathematics or variable size operands, and they round if an answer is inexact, much the way floats do. However, they provide compelling advantages over floats, including simpler hardware implementation that scales from as few as two-bit operands to thousands of bits. For any bit width, they have a larger dynamic range, higher accuracy, better closure under arithmetic operations, and simpler exception-handling. For example, posits never overflow to infinity or underflow to zero, and there is no "Not-a-Number" (NaN) value. Posits should take up less space to implement in silicon than an IEEE float of the same size. With fewer gate delays per operation as well as lower silicon footprint, the posit operations per second (POPS) supported by a chip can be significantly higher than the FLOPs using similar hardware resources. GPU accelerators, in particular, could do more arithmetic per watt and per dollar yet deliver superior answer quality.

A series of comprehensive benchmarks compares how many decimals of accuracy can be produced for a set number of bits-per-value, using various number formats. Low-precision posits provide a better solution than "approximate computing" methods that try to tolerate decreases in answer quality. High-precision posits provide better answers (more correct decimals) than floats of the same size, suggesting that in some cases, a 32-bit posit may do a better job than a 64-bit float. In other words, posits beat floats at their own game. 

Speaker Profile:
NUS Professor Dr. John L. Gustafson is an applied physicist and mathematician. He is a former Director at Intel Labs and former Chief Product Architect at AMD. A pioneer in high-performance computing, he introduced cluster computing in 1985 and first demonstrated scalable massively parallel performance on real applications in 1988. This became known as Gustafson's Law, for which he won the inaugural ACM Gordon Bell Prize. He is also a recipient of the IEEE Computer Society's Golden Core Award.

Sponsors:
This event is sponsored by NUS Enterprise.
events.location: SR5, Town Plaza, University Town, NUS, , Singapore

events.name: TGIFHacks #65 - Building Chatbots
events.description:
This workshop will be about creating bots using Django. The first part of the seminar will focus on setting up a Django-based bot server that can be used with Telegram/Facebook through an event-based interface. Subsequently you will learn how to create more responsive bot servers that work via websockets. During the course of the talk, there will also be discussions on the different aspects of making a chatbot intelligent and engaging.

Dr. Vaisagh Viswanathan is the co-founder and head of product and technology at impress.ai. impress.ai is an AI powered recruitment platform that generates chatbot based job interviews. It automatically interviews candidates and enhances efficiency of the recruiting process while reducing human bias. Previously Vaisagh led a team working on city-scale traffic simulations at TUM CREATE after completing his PhD from NTU on development of agent-based models for understanding human crowds.

Please bring along a laptop with the following:
1. internet connection
2. git 
3. python (tested on 2.7 but 3.4/3.5 should also work)
4. pip
5. virtual environment (pip install virtualenv)
6. install telegram (on your laptop)
events.location: The Nest Theatre @ Innovation Centre, , Singapore 63

events.name: Chinatown Pub Crawl with Speakers and Participants of FOSSASIA OpenTech Summit
events.description:
Let's get together with speakers and participants of the FOSSASIA OpenTech Summit for a pub, dessert and snack crawl and explore Singapore Sling, Chinese desserts and snacks we find on our way.  Approximate Itinerary: 7:00 - 7:15 Chinatown MRT, Exit A below the escalator, near the red (OCBC) ATM<a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=Pagoda+St%2C+Singapore%2C+sg"></a> 7:15 - 8:30 Visit Food Centre (Good Beer Company in particular!) 8:30 - 8:45 Walking to Brewerkz 8:45 onwards at Brewerkz  Contact Call Roland on +65 9670 0022 if you can't find us! 



More Info FOSSASIA: http://2017.fossasia.org Brewerkz: http://www.brewerkz.com
events.location: Chinatown MRT, Exit A below the escalator, near the red (OCBC) ATM, Pagoda St, Singapore
